fig.title: DITA map defining hierarchy for topics
fig.p: In this example, there are six topicref elements. They are nested and have a hierarchical relationship. bats.dita is the parent topic and the other topics are its children.
fig.codeblock: <map title="Bats"> <topicref href="bats.dita"> <topicref href="bat-caring.dita"/> <topicref href="bat-feeding.dita"/> <topicref href="bat-sonar.dita"/> <topicref href="bat-guano.dita/> <topicref href="bat-history.dita"/> </topicref> </map>

fig.title: DITA map defining relationship between topics
fig.p: In the example, the collection-type attribute is used to specify that the topics should be read in a sequential order.
fig.codeblock: <map title="Bats"> <topicref href="bats.dita" collection-type="sequence"> <topicref href="bat-caring.dita"/> <topicref href="bat-feeding.dita"/> <topicref href="bat-sonar.dita"/> <topicref href="bat-guano.dita/> <topicref href="bat-history.dita"/> </topicref> </map>

draft-comment.author: Kristen J Eberlein
draft-comment.p: I think this topic should have lots of examples that demonstrate what can be done by setting attributes. The topicref element is core (and unique) to DITA. Originally, the topic made reference to collection-type and linking. Try and illustrate the most important base behaviors.
Need examples that use non-DITA references.
